page.title: 12Chertsey Bridge
page.content: The first bridge was of wood,built in 1410 and was maintained by the Abbot of Chertsey Abbey on whose land it was built. Then, as its condition deteriorated it was repaired, but uneffectively, so in 1780 James Paine was commissioned to design a new stone bridge. Costing Â£7,325, the 5-arch bridge did not actually reach the banks, so Â£2,800 was needed for completion, in 1785. 200 years later, the bridge stands strong, and on Sunday 9th June, the residents of Chertsey celebrated its continuous existence, and the Mayor revealed a plaque in its honour. Claims to fame include a mention in Charles Dicken's "Oliver Twist," and was recently the setting for a Channel 4 T.V. programme "Fairly Secret Army."
